description: Because of its limited solubility it is only effective when added directly to the mash. Use for making dark beers in areas of soft water. Use nomograph and monitor the mash pH with pH test papers to determine how much to add.
Useful for adding calcium if the water is low in sulfate. Can be used to add sulfate "crispness" to the hop bitterness.
Useful for adding Calcium if the water is low in chlorides.

effects: Lowers pH by a small amount.
description: Can be used to add sulfate "crispness" to the hop bitterness.
If your pH is too low and/or has low residual alkalinity, then you can add alkalinity. See procedure for calcium carbonate.

name: Chalk
description: Because of its limited solubility it is only effective when added directly to the mash. Use for making dark beers in areas of soft water. Use nomograph and monitor the mash pH with pH test papers to determine how much to add.

name: Epsom Salt
effects: Lowers pH by a small amount.
description: Can be used to add sulfate "crispness" to the hop bitterness.

name: Gypsum
description: Useful for adding calcium if the water is low in sulfate. Can be used to add sulfate "crispness" to the hop bitterness.
Adding phosphoric acid is the easiest way to lower the pH of sparge water without adding undesirable flavors. Usually around 3-5 mL per 5 gallons.

name: Baking Soda
description: If your pH is too low and/or has low residual alkalinity, then you can add alkalinity. See procedure for calcium carbonate.
Useful for adding Calcium if the water is low in chlorides.

name: Chalk
description: Because of its limited solubility it is only effective when added directly to the mash. Use for making dark beers in areas of soft water. Use nomograph and monitor the mash pH with pH test papers to determine how much to add.

name: Epsom Salt
effects: Lowers pH by a small amount.
description: Can be used to add sulfate "crispness" to the hop bitterness.
Useful for adding Calcium if the water is low in chlorides.
Adding lactic acid will lower the pH of sparge water, however too much and it will sour your beer. Usually around 7 mL per 5 gallons.
Adding phosphoric acid is the easiest way to lower the pH of sparge water without adding undesirable flavors. Usually around 3-5 mL per 5 gallons.

name: Gypsum
description: Useful for adding calcium if the water is low in sulfate. Can be used to add sulfate "crispness" to the hop bitterness.
